Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a high resolution Q-TOF Mass Spectrometer
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) program, Professor Mande Holford from CUNY Hunter College and colleagues Charles Drain and Clifford Soll will acquire a high definition quadrupole time-of-flight (Q-TOF) liquid-chromatography mass spectrometer (LC/MS). The proposal is aimed at enhancing research training and education at all levels, especially in areas such as (a) small molecules; (b) biopolymers; (c) natural products discovery from complex mixtures; (d) combinatorial libraries; (e) biophysics involving intact proteins or enzymatic digests; (f) scaffolds for nanotechnology materials; and (g) functionalized lipids and dyes.

Mass spectrometry vaporizes and ionizes a sample by a variety of methods. The particles (parent and fragment ions) flow into a mass spectrometer where their mass/charge ratios are measured. This highly sensitive technique allows determination of the masses of the particles, their chemical composition and enables one to deduce the structure of the substances in a complex mixture. An LC/MS combines the physical separation capability of liquid chromatography with the mass analysis ability of mass spectrometry. The liquid chromatograph separates a mixture into its molecular components. These components flow into a mass spectrometer where they are ionized into the parent ion and its fragment ions and their masses are measured. The instrumentation provided by this award will provide faculty and students the opportunity to pursue advanced research projects at CUNY-Hunter College. It will be available for use to faculty and students across the campuses in the CUNY system. It will advance the training of many students in the use of this important and widely employed analytical technique and will advance research in chemistry, materials research, nanotechnology and biochemistry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award was used to acquire an Agilent Q­TOF mass spectrometer for The City University of New York Mass Spectrometry Facility located at Hunter College. Acquisition of this state-of-the art mass spectrometer fulfills the specific objective of having the CUNY Mass Spectrometry Facility serve as a catalyst for internal and external collaborations enabling CUNY researchers to reach new levels of scientific achievement. The Q-TOF mass spectrometer is used to advance a broad range of research projects related to: (a) small molecules, (b) biopolymers, (c) natural products discovery from complex mixtures, (d) combinatorial libraries, (e) biophysics researchers working with intact proteins or enzymatic digests, (f) scaffolds for nanotechnology materials, (g) functionalized lipids and dyes. Throughout the life of the award  greater than 3000 samples were analyzed and 22 manuscripts were published in peer-reviewed scientific journals.

The Q­TOF instrument serves a core research and training function for a significant number of CUNY faculty and students. Education and training in the science of Mass Spectrometry is accomplished in three overlapping ways: (1) Teaching Mass Spectrometry as a primary research tool to examine the structural details of molecules via one­on­one interactions and at seminars with the facility Director Dr. Yoo. (2) The CUNY Mass Spectrometry Facility participates in demonstrating the concepts of Mass Spectrometry and/or providing laboratory experiences for several undergraduate courses: Analytical Chemistry, Instrumental Analysis, and Inorganic Chemistry offered at Hunter College. (3) The CUNY MS facility provides demonstrations to high school and undergraduate students in the Math & Science Partnership program to expand Mass Spectrometry outreach and educational activities. This level of training ensures that these scholars will have a greater proficiency for how to apply Mass Spectrometry in their scientific pursuits.
